Early immunotherapy—high‐dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day ×3–5 days), followed by steroid taper plus IVIG (2 g/kg monthly) and cyclophosphamide or rituximab—has been shown to reduce relapse rates and long-term disability (AAN practice update 2023).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Progressive muscle weakness and fasciculations
 • Represents amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a motor neuron disease without retinal or cochlear involvement.
 • Misconception: fasciculations imply neuropathy rather than microvascular endotheliopathy.
 • Key differentiator: ALS presents with LMN and UMN signs, not visual field defects or hearing loss.

C. Episodic memory loss and personality changes
 • Suggests frontotemporal dementia or limbic encephalitis, lacking ocular or auditory pathology.
 • Misconception: encephalopathy alone equates to Susac; fails to consider multi-organ involvement.
 • Key differentiator: Susac’s cognitive changes accompany BRAO and hearing loss.

D. Sudden onset hemiparesis and aphasia
 • Typical of a large-vessel ischemic stroke, not small-vessel endotheliopathy.
 • Misconception: any acute neurological deficit implies Susac; overlooks territorial infarction patterns.
 • Key differentiator: stroke imaging shows a vascular territory infarct, not multifocal corpus callosum lesions.

Comparison Table

FeatureSusac SyndromeALSFrontotemporal DementiaStroke
PathophysiologyAutoimmune microangiopathyMotor neuron degenerationFrontal lobe neurodegenerationLarge‐vessel thrombosis/embolism
Key Clinical FindingsBRAO, sensorineural hearing loss, encephalopathyMuscle weakness, fasciculations, dysphagiaMemory loss, personality changesHemiparesis, aphasia
OnsetSubacute, relapsingInsidious, progressiveInsidious, progressiveSudden
MRICentral corpus callosum “snowballs”Typically normalFrontal lobe atrophyTerritorial infarct
Diagnostic TestFluorescein angiography, audiometryEMGNeuropsychological testingCT/MRI vascular imaging

Clinical Pearls

- The classic triad is present in only ~13% at onset; early BRAO or hearing loss may precede encephalopathy by months.
• Central corpus callosum “snowball” lesions on MRI are virtually pathognomonic.
• Prompt initiation of combination immunotherapy (steroids + IVIG ± rituximab) within weeks of symptom onset correlates with better outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing Susac as MS: MS lesions are periventricular and ovoid (“Dawson’s fingers”), whereas Susac lesions are central in the corpus callosum.
2. Attributing hearing loss to Menière’s disease or age-related presbycusis, missing concurrent BRAO or MRI findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Susac Consortium (JNNP 2016): Consensus diagnostic criteria requiring ≥2 of BRAO, sensorineural hearing loss, encephalopathy. (Level IV evidence)
2. American Academy of Neurology Practice Update (Neurology 2023): Recommends high‐dose IV steroids plus adjunctive IVIG and rituximab/cyclophosphamide early in disease course. (Level C evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Autoimmune endotheliopathy targets precapillary arterioles in:
• Corpus callosum (central fibers → encephalopathy)
• Retina (branch arterioles → visual field deficits)
• Cochlea (stria vascularis microcirculation → hearing loss)

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Anti‐endothelial cell antibodies activate complement, causing focal microvascular necrosis, blood-brain barrier breakdown, and microinfarctions in CNS, retina, and cochlea.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in young adult with unexplained visual or auditory symptoms ± encephalopathy
2. Funduscopic exam + fluorescein angiography for BRAO
3. Pure‐tone audiometry and brainstem‐evoked responses
4. Brain MRI with FLAIR/T2 to identify corpus callosum lesions
5. Exclude infections, systemic vasculitis, ADEM
6. Initiate immunosuppression

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2/FLAIR central “snowball” and linear “spoke” lesions in corpus callosum
• Punctate leptomeningeal enhancement in acute phase

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day ×3–5 days then taper
• IVIG 2 g/kg monthly
• Cyclophosphamide 500–1,000 mg/m² monthly or rituximab 375 mg/m² weekly ×4

Board Examination Focus

Susac syndrome is most often tested via short clinical vignettes emphasizing the triad and MRI corpus callosum findings. This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Recognizing early ocular or cochlear signs before full triad develops is a frequently examined point on neuroimmunology and vasculitis questions.

question_text: A female patient presents with central nervous system manifestations, including hearing loss and retinal artery occlusion. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Susac syndrome is a rare microvascular endotheliopathy characterized by the triad of encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusions (BRAO), and sensorineural hearing loss. Autoimmune-mediated occlusion of precapillary arterioles in the brain (especially corpus callosum), retina, and cochlea leads to microinfarctions. BRAO produces visual field deficits seen on fluorescein angiography; cochlear ischemia causes low-to-mid frequency hearing loss on audiometry; corpus callosum “snowball” lesions appear on MRI. Early recognition and immunosuppression can prevent irreversible organ damage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Susac syndrome is defined by the clinical triad and confirmed with imaging and lab studies:
• Retinal fluorescein angiography: BRAO with arterial wall hyperfluorescence (Susac Consortium, 2017).
• MRI: Central corpus callosum T2 hyperintensities (“snowballs”) and diffusion restriction in acute phases.
• Audiometry: Bilateral low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
Early aggressive therapy—high-dose IV methylprednisolone followed by tapering oral steroids plus monthly IVIG—has been shown to reduce relapse rates and long-term deficits (Au et al., Neurology 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CADASIL
• CADASIL features recurrent subcortical strokes, migraines, cognitive decline, and anterior temporal white matter hyperintensities. It lacks BRAO and hearing loss.
• Misconception: Equating any small‐vessel white matter disease with Susac.

C. Multiple sclerosis
• MS presents with demyelinating plaques, optic neuritis, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia. It does not cause vascular occlusions of retinal arteries or sensorineural hearing loss.
• Misconception: Attributing any young woman with CNS lesions to MS.

D. Neuromyelitis optica
• NMO causes longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis and severe optic neuritis via AQP4-IgG. It does not involve retinal artery occlusion or cochlear infarction.
• Misconception: Confusing optic nerve involvement with retinal vascular pathology.

Comparison Table

FeatureSusac syndromeCADASILMultiple sclerosisNeuromyelitis optica
Retinal artery occlusion+ (BRAO)–––
Sensorineural hearing loss+ (low-frequency)–––
MRI corpus callosum lesionsCentral “snowballs”Anterior temporal & periventric.Periventricular “Dawson’s fingers”Spinal cord ≥3 segments
PathophysiologyAutoimmune microangiopathyNOTCH3-mediated arteriopathyAutoimmune demyelinationAQP4-IgG astrocytopathy

Clinical Pearls

1. The Susac triad may present incompletely; maintain suspicion with isolated BRAO or unexplained bilateral low-frequency hearing loss.
2. MRI “snowball” lesions in the central corpus callosum distinguish Susac from MS and CADASIL.
3. Initiate immunosuppression early (steroids + IVIG) to prevent permanent deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing Susac as MS in young women with multifocal brain lesions delays proper treatment.
2. Omitting fluorescein angiography in patients with hearing loss and visual symptoms can miss BRAO.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Susac Consortium Consensus (2016): Induction with IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day ×3–5 days, followed by oral prednisone and monthly IVIG; consider cyclophosphamide for severe disease (expert opinion, level III).
2. Au et al., Neurology (2020): Retrospective cohort demonstrating that early combination of steroids, IVIG, and mycophenolate reduced relapse rate by 70% (level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions localize to precapillary arterioles supplying the central corpus callosum (causing snowball lesions), retinal branch arterioles (causing BRAO), and cochlear capillaries (causing hearing loss).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune-mediated endothelial injury activates complement, causing arteriolar occlusion and microinfarcts in brain white matter, retina, and cochlea.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with triad features
2. Brain MRI for callosal lesions
3. Fluorescein angiography for BRAO and arterial wall hyperfluorescence
4. Audiometry for low-frequency hearing loss
5. Initiate immunotherapy promptly

Neuroimaging Pearls

Round T2 hyperintensities (“snowballs”) in the central corpus callosum are characteristic and help differentiate from MS’s periventricular lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day for 3–5 days → oral prednisone taper + monthly IVIG. For refractory cases, add cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Susac syndrome is frequently tested as a triad-based vignette, often highlighting BRAO and characteristic MRI findings.

question_text: Which type of visual field defect is characterized by a loss of vision in one eye?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Visual field defects map directly to lesion location along the afferent visual pathway.
• Lesions of the retina or optic nerve (anterior to the chiasm) cause monocular field loss.
• Compression at the optic chiasm (e.g., pituitary adenoma) yields bitemporal hemianopia by affecting decussating nasal fibers.
• Post-chiasmal lesions (optic tract, radiations, occipital cortex) produce homonymous defects affecting identical halves of both eyes.
• A scotoma is a localized deficit (central or paracentral), not a global loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Monocular vision loss refers to complete loss of perception in one eye due to pathology anterior to the chiasm (optic nerve or retina). Recognition is based on confrontation testing and formal automated perimetry, often accompanied by a relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus Gunn pupil) in optic nerve lesions. Miller’s Textbook of Neurology (8th ed, 2020) and the American Academy of Ophthalmology’s Preferred Practice Patterns for Optic Neuritis (2018) emphasize using visual field patterns and pupillary responses to localize lesions to the optic nerve.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Central scotoma
• Incorrect: confines loss to central 5–10° (macula/fovea), not the entire eye.
• Misconception: equating focal central defects with global visual loss.

C. Bitemporal hemianopia
• Incorrect: loss of temporal fields in both eyes due to chiasmal compression.
• Differentiator: patients retain nasal (medial) fields, not total monocular loss.

D. Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
• Incorrect: loss of the same side (left or right) half-fields in both eyes from post-chiasmal lesions.
• Differentiator: affects halves of both eyes, not one whole eye.

Comparison Table

Defect TypeField Loss PatternLesion Location
Monocular vision lossEntire visual field of one eyeRetina or optic nerve (anterior to chiasm)
Central scotomaCentral 5–10° (macular region)Macula/foveal retina
Bitemporal hemianopiaTemporal halves, both eyesOptic chiasm (crossing nasal fibers)
Contralateral homonymous hemianopiaSame side halves, both eyesOptic tract, radiations, occipital cortex

Clinical Pearls

- Always assess for a relative afferent pupillary defect when monocular vision loss is suspected.
• Confrontation testing is a rapid bedside screen; confirm with automated perimetry.
• In giant cell arteritis, urgent ESR/CRP and temporal artery biopsy are indicated when monocular vision loss occurs to prevent involvement of the fellow eye.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing a scotoma (localized defect) with monocular vision loss (global defect).
• Mixing up terms heteronymous (bitemporal) versus homonymous hemianopias.
• Overlooking acute monocular loss as an optic neuropathy requiring emergent evaluation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Visual field defect patterns and their anatomic localization are frequently tested on neurology and ophthalmology boards, often via diagrams, perimetry plots, or clinical vignettes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials
